nodes.body:
Traditional grammars refer to this marker as འབྲེལ་སྒྲ་, literally “link sound,” “relation sound,” and it is commonly translated by the English “of.”

The genitive has several variant forms depending on the final letter of the preceding word. These variants are: གི་, གྱི་, ཀྱི་, འི་

  • འི་ is used after a vowel and འ་
  • གི་ is used after ག་, ང་
  • ཀྱི་ is used after ད་, བ་, ས་, and the ད་དྲག་
  • གྱི་ is used after ན་, མ་, ར་, ལ་

In Classical Tibetan, vowels and the letter འ་ may be followed by the variant ཡི་; this is especially true in poetry, to suit the requirements of the meter.

The genitive is used not only to form noun complements, possessive pronouns, and adjectives, but also relative clauses. In this case, it may be translated by a relative pronoun such as “that,” “who,” “where,” etc. The complement that is marked by the genitive always precedes the noun to which it refers.

  • ངའི་གྲོགས་པོ་ “My friend” (Literally: “The friend of me”)
  • ཁོང་གི་ཕྱག་སྨྱུག་ “His pen” (Literally: “The pen of him”)
  • བཀྲ་ཤིས་ལགས་ཀྱི་བུ་ “Trashi’s son”
  • བླ་མའི་སླློབ་མ་ “The lama’s disciple”
  • གཞུང་གི་ལས་བྱེད་པ་ “Government civil servant”
  • དགེ་རྒན་གྱི་དེབ་ “The teacher’s book”
  • དེབ་ནང་ལ་ཡོད་པའི་པར་ “The photo that’s in the book”

In the literary language the genitive case may also correspond to the conjunction “but.”
nodes.title: About The Genitive Case (གི་)
